instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the backlight on the LCD screen, this is necessary to get the screen to light up..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight  [solved]
threads.message:
Hi I have a liquid damaged Air with no display.

I've changed over a slightly burnt LVDS connector, change a couple of ugly looking caps and replaced <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and tried another screen also.
I'm still getting no backlight and I'm stuck.

I'm getting a display though

8.5v on L7701 <SIGNAL>LCDBLT_BOOST</SIGNAL>
8.5v on <SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>
2.8v on <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_DIV_L</SIGNAL>
3.2v on <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
3.2v on <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>

<RESISTOR>R7717</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R7722</RESISTOR> all 0 ohm

On <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>:

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> on <CAPACITOR>C7710</CAPACITOR> = 5.02v
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> = 2.8v
<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> = 1.45v
<RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> = 198k
<RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> = 91.6k

Any help would be really appreciated

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight  [solved]
threads.message:
Try 2-3 times PRAM reset first.

Did you inspect XW77200?
Some pictures available on the forum.

Be sure to get (very) similar diode mode readings on all return resistors.

If still the same, remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and run a wire from <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR> to <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight  [solved]
threads.message:
I searched XW7720 on the forum but couldn’t find a picture of it.
I’ve attached what I think might be the correct trace but I’m probably wrong.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight  [solved]
threads.message: Yeah on closer inspection, I’d say that was f’d

threads.message: Fixed and I now have a backlight. Thank you [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER]
